Artin-Schreier sequences and motivic homotopy

Jul 26, 2020

In this post, I would like to record the following observation, whose origin I haven’t been able to track down, but I learnt it from Elden Elmanto and Robert Burklund, and Robert told me he learned it from Tom Bachmann. I think it probably dates all the way back to Voevodsky. The statement is the following: let be a smooth scheme of characteristic ; then, the -completion of the etale stable motivic category (where you replace Nisnevich sheaves by etale sheaves) is zero. The argument is as follows: the Artin-Schreier map , given locally by , has kernel given by the constant etale sheaf . Therefore, . This implies that multiplication by is invertible in , and so the -completion of this category is zero. In particular, is invertible in any -invariant etale sheaf of spectra on smooth -schemes.

This situation is pretty reminiscent of the story prior to the discovery of crystalline cohomology in the 60’s: -adic etale cohomology at the characteristic does not behave well. This leads one to hope that there may be a “crystalline” version of the etale stable motivic category for schemes of characteristic , which is better behaved in the sense that its -completion doesn’t just vanish. Based on our above discussion, we need to either discard -invariance or etale descent. Let’s keep -invariance, so we need to think of a replacement for etale descent.

The conceptual issue that I run into when thinking about this question is that etale cohomology is inherently constructible (locally constant sheaves and the like), while crystalline cohomology is inherently coherent. So (and this is true of both Weil cohomologies and the motivic category) over a base of characteristic , our objects of interest “degenerate” from the constructible world away from to the coherent world at . What we might look for, therefore, is an “object” interpolating between the constructible/etale world away from and the coherent/crystalline world at .

In the Weil cohomology theory world, there is such an object, described by BMS, using the ring . So, it is natural to ask: is there is a “” which specializes to (the -linearization of) ?

I talked briefly with Elden about this circle of ideas (who has a lot more ideas on this stuff; see also his recent paper here), and it seems like a pretty fun thing to think about.
